description: Either a back-formation from prolongation, or from Old French prolonguer or porloignier, from Latin prōlongō, from prō + longō. Doublet of purloin.

verbs.description: prolong (third-person singular simple present prolongs, present participle prolonging, simple past and past participle prolonged)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To extend in space or length.
(transitive) To lengthen in time; to extend the duration of
(transitive) To put off to a distant time; to postpone.
examples: The government shouldn't prolong deciding on this issue any further.
